comments.commentBody:
Magnus beat us with ease. Very nice PR event for chess.
Next time maybe we can play against Liv Tyler.
Shirov's play in this tournament was very sharp. He earned the victory.
Bobby Fischer is also a past NY State Champion (Poughkeepsie 1963).
agreed with lefthandsketch.  they make a big publicity push saying they need to promote chess in the big cities, but don't invite the public to attend.  very bad marketing move.

Simple and clean hotel. It is perfectly located in Sultanahmet, a nice walk to the Blue Mosque, Hagia Sofia, Topkapi Arasta bazaar and tram station.

The staff were accommodating and happy to give us an extra pillow and extra sheet when requested.

The only disappointment was I initally tried to book a room at the sister hotel, but there was only a basement room available there, which I told them I didn't want as I prefer not to be in the basement, so instead I was offered a room at the their sister hotel. So then I was a little surprised on the day we arrived to be shown to a room in the basement! When I enquired as to why this was the case since I had turned down another room because it was in the basement I was told it was the only one left now. (I booked 3months in advance).

In any case it was spacious and clean. The bathroom has a proper shower cubicle with a strong hot water. Breakfast is served on the terrace which looks over the Hagis Sophia Church. For breakfast we had bread, eggs, cheese, yellow cheese, olives, yoghurt and marmalades, tea and coffee. The juice is not fresh (tastes like bad) but overall it is good value. We paid 75 euros/night. They also offer a private transfer to or from the international airport for 15 euro, or can organise a pickup with the shuttle van on the way back for 5 euro per person.

There are many good restaurants in the area and lots of friendly cats about the streets. we liked the Halil ?brahaim Sofrasi restaurant near the Bazaar only a 10 min walk away. They are open 24hrs, and have live Turkish music till midnight. It's very relaxed for dinner and apple tea (but no alcohol is sold there).

The Staff was excellent and the day reception even let me beat him at Backgammon.

When I am in Istanbul again, I will definitely stay at the Adamar Hotel, again!
www.adamarhotel.com

As a descendant of two families of German emigrants who couldn't even stand Bismarck, let alone the psychos who followed after him, there's an answer to any identity question- Have a look at German culture in the mid 19th century. It was a very different, much more focused place. German culture was famous even in Europe for its high quality, and Germany was a major tourist destination which people raved about, even the English writer Jerome K. Jerome, in "On the Bummel" and "Diary of a Pilgrimage".

History can't, and shouldn't, rule the future. In the case of Germany, there's been some misrepresentation, too. The Nazis didn't invent Germany, nor were they universally loved in Germany. The German people had practical ways of expressing themselves about the Nazis, even during the war. An uncle of mine was on one of his regular escapes from POW camp and was picked up at a railway station by the Gestapo. A German soldier noticed and came over and said "It's OK, he's with me," getting rid of the Gestapo. He then more or less said, "Have a nice war" to my uncle, and went away. (Thanks, mate, on behalf of the family, whoever you were, by the way.)

Germany should just be itself. An identity is who you really are, not who someone else says you are.

The Germans have a lot to be proud of. If anyone looks at the Morgenthau Plan, devised by Henry Morgenthau (the US secretary of treasury) during WW2, you will see that many had plans to completely demolish the German state. This is no conspiracy theory, but historical fact. You can google it, wikipedia it, etc. The German people have always produced in a way that looks towards the social welfare for their fellow countrymen and women. Individuals like Soros simply want the Germans to foot the bill and dilute any power that comes from that country, much like Morgenthau many years before. Soros wants to maintain a world where financiers and those who manipulate financial markets have all the power, while countries like Germany that work hard and create jobs that actually produce something foot the bill and keep the peace. It is time for the German people to reawaken to their true potential, look after their own country, and stop letting the talking heads, many who have created a financial catastrophe in this country, dictate their policy and economic agenda.

Those of us born during the Nazi period know that the real purpose of the European Union is to contain Germany. Since young Germans don't feel responsible for WW II, they don't feel guilty about being German or the need to hide as a "European."

The UN will be here in 2020 but I am not so sure about the EU. And the Deutschmark will be back!

Its about time. An entire generation that knew nothing of the war have taken control and endless apology is neither good for Germany or the world.

During WWII my mother singlehandedly defeated Hitler and opened they way for me as Jew to have normal relations with Germans. Every Wednesday my mother gave an impromptu recital of German composers for the neighborhood kids; her message was that Germany was one of the pillars of Western civilization and composers not Hitler represented the true Germany.

This is a timely and extremely important essay that might well have found space on page-1.  Western civilization's debt to Germany remained unpaid as a result of the two world wars of the 20th century; nor was the record compiled by Germany in relation to those events worthy of forgiveness.  But history's memory extends over centuries, not years, and it would be simply nonsensical for the German-speaking people to continue the ritual of political and cultural hibernation now into the 21st century.  They would be wise to alert both immigrants and the native-Left that there is no longer room for Germany bashing, and that this great nation and great people are -- and must be seen to be -- an integral part in the preservation and promulgation of Western values and Western justice.  The last thing needed by a renewed German sense of itself is the tolerant inclusion of Jew-haters, this time led by Islamic fundamentalists.  What made Germany great was a cosmopolitanism that rejected all that was puny, vulgar and local.  This is the nation of Goethe, Frederick the Great, Beethoven, Mozart, Helmholtz.., the list is so very long and its dignitaries illuminate the arena in which today's fashionable lefties are seen to be pathetic and hopelessly out of place.
The Germans are the smartest and hardest working people in today's world.  The past is gone.  The future will be very bright for Germans.

I think a smart town would simply have found one of no doubt a few ordinances the 'pastor' would have been violating and let it be known he would be quickly shut down. I don't know a town left that allows the burning of leaves, much less piles of paper and leather.

I lived in Gainesville for a couple years after high school. It is, as this article describes, largely a hippie-ish college town full of progressives. However, like most college towns in the south, it is surrounded by a sea of countrified redneck ignorance and bigotry. Understandably, most residents are not okay with the hate-mongering preached by this pastor. Who can blame them for taking a stand? Hopefully, Muslims the world over will recognize the difference between an extremist bigot and the majority of people who are tolerant of religious diversity.

What the good people of Gainesville ought to do is completely and totally shun the man (and probably the entirety of his congregation). Refuse to speak to him, refuse to acknowledge him, refuse to admit his existence in any way, shape, or form. Simply act as if he doesn't exist.

I think he'd get the hint pretty quickly.

Jones is just another of the infinite number of lunatics in this country who want their 15 minutes. People will now riot and get violent in the Muslim world because the media, for whatever reasons, has made a mountain out of a moronic molehill. Thus the media has to be held responsible for whatever chaos and loss of life that ensues.

This man does not represent Gainesville at all!  As a community, we are appalled at his actions and as a community have been actively working to counter his messages of hate and intolerance.  Many events are being held this week and tomorrow to promote tolerance, acceptance and unity.  The world needs to know this  organization is only 30 people and are basically shunned in Gainesville.  We are a progressive community and in no way want this person or his followers to be associated with us.

As an educator, I am always trying to teach my students that prejudice, intolerance, hatred - all lead to bloodshed, violence, and war.  But tonight, as I watch re-runs of 9/11, I'm finding it hard not to hate.  I have been totally opposed to this pastor in Florida's burning of the Koran, but then I think of Osama Bin Laden and his ilk.  They didn't burn books.  They burned over 3000 human lives . . . Never forget.

I would like to suggest that all Christian Churches raise money to build Christian Churches in the Middle East, what is fair is fair , they build mosque here we build there. The only difference would be the muslims would not allow us to express freedom of religion and according to the Quran/Koran kill westerners. so if their so called bible tell them to kill us , why do keep allowing them into our country. But really let's collect a few million dollars to build a christian church, god knows they need work over there, we would be helping there economy how nice would that be, however if they burn our bible in the middle east we can't say a thing unlike here how traggic that the people here are so blind to what the untimate goal is of islam, they want one government one world government run by islam. i suggest to people out to read revelations it explains all that is happening now. of the over 260 prophesies in the Holy Bible some 180+ have come to pass already, that is the fact, read, learn, study what the bible says, just for curiosity sake if anything.

Action of the residents of Gainesville is commendable. If more people find the courage to stand against something that they find to be unjust and indecent, then the world would be a better place to live.

On my part, I am going to make a copy of this article and send it to all the newspapers in Pakistan, my country of birth, so that people over there can see how important it is to stand up against injustice, whether in the name of religion, race or creed.

It's good that President Obama spoke out about this issue.

Americans must respect the symbols all religions; from President Obama's lips to our ears.

We'll probably hear about other instances of disrespect, in this country, towards various religions. Hopefully the president will remain vigilant.

I suspect that if the news media, which has helped fuel this frenzy, would simply publish the names and addresses of the Dove members, this whole thing would come to an end. People are willing to do a whole lot while anonymous, but not so much when people know who they are.

Perhaps on 9/11 between 6 PM and 9 PM, Terry Jones can eschew burning the Korans, and have a friendly invitation to draw a positive likeness of Mohammed. Local artists and children can draw positive images of the Prophet. The best drawings can be auctioned off with the proceeds going to support Afghanistan orphans.

No burn permit needed, freedom of speech, and supporting orphans.
What could possibly go wrong with this alternative?

Jones represents the worst of American society, but it now appears his actions have made the best find their voice. It is always a beautiful sight to see good average Americans draw a line in the sand where bigotry and ignorance can not cross. Having watched the overwhelming public response to Jones and Dove, it should remind us all of the truly unique American spirit of tolerance and justice that is  immovable, unflinching and lasting.

Let us not forget that the pastor has not caused physical harm to anyone. The protests in Afghanistan over the koran burning turned deadly because of the mentality of the people who protested; they were not pushed to deadly violence as a result of the pastor.
How can a city disown a patriot with out a means to express his anger? Maybe he is burning a page for every soldier that die? No he would need a few more than one Quran burning for that.
